docs.lead_paragraph: MOVE over Prozac, Xanax and all the other balms for the distressed in current vogue: scientists are heralding a new generation of designer drugs, psychiatric medications more powerful, quicker acting and with fewer unwanted effects. A handful of the new medications are undergoing the first phase of tests in patients and should reach the market within the next five years; others are merely glimmers in the eyes of psychopharmacologists.

headline.main: Research on Brain Leads to Pursuit Of Designer Drugs

docs.abstract: Scientists work on new generation of psychiatric drugs that are more powerful, quicker-acting and have fewer side effects than drugs now in use; advances stem from neuroscience research initiative of National Institute of Mental Health, called 'Decade of the Brain'; Dr Steven Hyman discusses startling revelation that there may be one hundred or more variations of a given receptor protein in brain cell, rather than just one or two; 15 different receptors have been found for serotonin, neurotransmitter involved in depression, 5 receptors for dopamine, implicated in schizophrenia, 6 kinds for norepinephrine and many more for GABA, both of which play roles in anxiety disorders and depression; diagram; pharmaceutical scientists Steven M Paul and James Heym foresee many improved medications (M)
docs.snippet: MOVE over Prozac, Xanax and all the other balms for the distressed in current vogue: scientists are heralding a new generation of designer drugs, psychiatric medications more powerful, quicker acting and with fewer unwanted effects.    A handful of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Now that Gov. George E. Pataki has released his long-awaited plan to reconstruct the state's $4 billion welfare system, the debate has shifted to the Legislature, where many Democrats are already vowing to block major portions of his initiative. The 300-page bill the Governor unveiled last week called for cutting benefits to families by 45 percent over four years and ending them entirely after five, and replacing cash grants to able-bodied childless adults with vouchers for food, clothing and shelter. If enacted, the plan would represent the most thorough revision of state welfare policies in six decades and significantly change the lives of 1.4 million recipients.

headline.main: OPPOSITION LOOMS FOR WELFARE BILL OFFERED BY PATAKI

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki's release of long-awaited plan to reconstruct New York State's $4 billion welfare system shifts debate to Legislature, where many Democrats are already vowing to block major portions of initiative; broad sampling of Assembly Democrats show many strongly question, if not outright reject, several important provisions in Pataki plan, particularly those that would cut benefits for families; outlook for proposals remains unclear since even though Democrats control Assembly by comfortable 95-54 margin, they are far from united in opposition; many conservatives are likely to cross party lines to endorse parts of it; emboldened by Democrats' strong showing in recent elections, liberals and some moderates say they plan to mount strenuous campaign against Pataki's plan to wrest control of debate from Republicans (M)
